title: What are the dangers of cheating during tests and examinations? - Quora

response.answer_text: The repercussions for cheating on tests and exams depend on several factors: what level of education (I.e. middle school, high school, collegewhat the guidelines for the specific school say about cheating. The specific code of conduct at one school can be drastically different from another.Teachers/professors are probably the most important variable here. Some may watch for cheating more closely than others and some will “ignore” certain instances of cheating.What the test or exam is for. More important exams, such as those that result in obtaining a law or nursing degree, will most likely having harsher punishments compared to, say, a pop quiz for a reading assignment.The dangers of cheating: first and foremost, you fail yourself. Cheating is a result of poor study habits and lack of motivation. Not to mention it speaks volumes about an individual’s character. If you’re ok with cheating on tests and exams, what other sneaky and deceitful things are you capable of?cheating off of another person can also be dangerous because they may not be answering correctly.if you’re caught: receiving a 0%being labeled as untrustworthylosing points for your final gradebeing kicked out of the program/coursebeing expelled from the institutionUltimately, the dangers are numerous. Hope this helps!

Do you mean besides failing the course, having the cheating being reported to the appropriate administrative office, the accusation becoming a part of the students permanent file, and the possibility that the students would consequently be expelled from the university? There was a reason that I would report cheating whenever it occurred (and in my experience, it only rarely occurred). At my university, a report of academic dishonesty would be placed in the student’s file. If, however, a second such report was submitted, expulsion from the university was nearly automatic. Because of that, I would explain to the student involved that as long as there was not already a report of cheating in their file, the only consequence would be an F in the course. But the risk of ever cheating again in their remaining time at the university was quite high - they would likely be expelled.
